title: Bright lights, no city | News | bradfordera.com
text:
Oct 11, 2024 Oct 11, 2024 Updated 3 hrs ago Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email The Northern lights appeared as a vibrant red from Lafayette Township on Thursday evening. The sky had a slight reddish hue to the naked eye but as many amateur photographers found out, the color becomes much more vivid when captured with a camera. That happens for a number of reasons, including the light sensitivity of the human eye, exposure time, the photographer’s distance from sources of light pollution like cities, and a camera’s ability to detect more colors in the dark.
Era photo by Sara Furlong Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save The Northern lights appeared as a vibrant red from Lafayette Township on Thursday evening. The sky had a slight reddish hue to the naked eye but as many amateur photographers found out, the color becomes much more vivid when captured with a camera. That happens for a number of reasons, including the light sensitivity of the human eye, exposure time, the photographer’s distance from sources of light pollution like cities, and a camera’s ability to detect more colors in the dark.
